title: Analysis with tacmagic
text: Positron emission tomography (PET) research clinical imaging modality uses radioactive tracers bind target molecules interest. PET scanner identifies tracer location virtue tracer’s radioactive decay, providing information determine location target body. spatial resolution PET relatively poor, analysis frequently combined higher resolution imaging magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), can spatially co-registered PET image. Subsequently, radiotracer activity (time) can identified spatial region interest (ROI). image analysis pipeline required extract regional time activity curves (TACs) dynamic PET image. various pipelines available including widely-used commercial solutions (e.g. PMOD) newer open-source options (e.g. magia1). Pipelines generally implement following steps: Dynamic PET pre-processing (e.g. motion correction, decay-correction) PET image co-registration structural MRI MRI segmentation normalization atlas Various pipelines save TAC, volume related data various formats. package enables loading analysis TAC ROI volume data image analysis pipelines analysis R.

code: # Filename is a character string of the file's path on your computer. filename <- system.file("extdata", "AD06.tac", package="tacmagic") # Note: This file can also serve as a template if the TAC data is in some other  # format that is not yet supported.  AD06_tac <- load_tac(filename, format="PMOD") summary(AD06_tac)  #> tac object #>  Activity unit:           kBq/cc  #>  Time unit:               seconds  #>  Number of ROIs:          172  #>  Number of frames:        34  #>  Time span:               0 - 5400 seconds  #>  Unique frame durations:  15 30 60 180 300 600 seconds  AD06_tac[1:5,1:5] # the first 5 frames of the first 3 ROIs #>   start end FL_mid_fr_G_l FL_mid_fr_G_r FL_precen_G_l #> 1     0  15    0.05156934     0.0830544   -0.05035268 #> 2    15  30    5.76280770     5.9782509    6.15967912 #> 3    30  45   16.07137663    16.3756559   16.69802808 #> 4    45  60   19.11766922    19.4707593   18.52006408 #> 5    60  90   19.77191392    20.3383362   19.55189423 filename_acq <- system.file("extdata", "AD06.acqtimes", package="tacmagic") filename_voistat <- system.file("extdata", "AD06_TAC.voistat", package="tacmagic")  tac2 <- load_tac(filename_voistat, format="voistat", acqtimes=filename_acq)  all.equal(AD06_tac, tac2) #> [1] TRUE f_magia <- system.file("extdata", "AD06_tac_magia.mat", package="tacmagic")  AD06_tac_magia <- load_tac(f_magia, format="magia",                             time_unit="seconds", activity_unit="kBq/cc")  AD06_tac_magia[1:5,1:5] #>   start end        CGA         CGP          LOC #> 1     0  15  0.2070033  0.04986614 -0.001164075 #> 2    15  30  7.8729520  7.12711797  6.058719929 #> 3    30  45 16.6898445 17.37585231 18.097222061 #> 4    45  60 17.7306580 19.33122997 21.146157237 #> 5    60  90 18.9857118 19.57800502 22.009607171

title: Analysis with tacmagic
text: standardized uptake value ratio (\(SUVR\)) simple quantification PET activity commonly used many tracers including PIB. ratio tracer activity specified time period (\(Ct\)) target ROI reference region. Using ratio allows factors normally required calculate \(SUV\) cancel , namely tracer dose patient body weight, therefore \(SUVR\) can calculated TAC data alone, .e. without need specify tracer dose body weight: \[SUVR = \frac{SUV_{TARGET}}{SUV_{REF}} = \frac{Ct_{TARGET}}{Ct_{REF}}\] literature, SUVR variably described calculated using mean activity frames specified time period, area curve. PIB, mean/summed activity used, time windows varied starting 40-50 minutes ending 60-90 minutes.3 suvr() function calculates SUVR regions TAC file based provided time information (vector frame start times) specified reference region (string). frames used different durations, weighted mean used. alternative method, using area curve mid-frame times x-axis available suvr_auc() provide similar results.
code: AD06_SUVR <- suvr(AD06,                       # TAC data                   SUVR_def=c(3000,3300,3600), # = 50-70 minute window                   ref="cerebellum"            # reference region in TAC data                   )  AD06_SUVR #>                    SUVR #> leftfrontal    2.070909 #> rightfrontal   2.200107 #> lefttemporal   2.043683 #> righttemporal  2.176933 #> leftparietal   2.054232 #> rightparietal  2.169382 #> leftoccipital  1.659831 #> rightoccipital 1.827765 #> leftcingulate  2.348674 #> rightcingulate 2.396375 #> frontal        2.136009 #> temporal       2.110140 #> parietal       2.112264 #> occipital      1.744258 #> cingulate      2.371747 #> cerebellum     1.000000 #> totalcortical  2.073093 #> leftdeep       1.788912 #> rightdeep      1.755389 #> deep           1.772272 #> ventricles     0.902195 #> whitematter    2.035768 #> amyloidcomp    2.231989 AD06_altSUVR <- suvr_auc(AD06, SUVR_def=c(3000,3300,3600), ref="cerebellum")  all.equal(AD06_SUVR, AD06_altSUVR) # Should be similar but not exact #> [1] "Component \"SUVR\": Mean relative difference: 0.007765957"

title: Background
text: Positron emission tomography (PET) research clinical imaging modality uses radioactive tracers bind target molecules interest. PET scanner identifies tracer location virtue tracer’s radioactive decay, providing information distribution target body. Analysis pipelines used calculate radiotracer activity time within spatial region interest (ROI). resulting time-activity curves (TAC) analyzed answer important clinical research questions using kinetic models [@Dierckx:2014].

title: Background
text: supporting multiple source data formats, tacmagic provides open R [@R] platform analysis PET TAC data produced existing image analysis pipelines. data loading functions provide common format subsequent analysis R. also implemented basic non-invasive models commonly used PET research [@Lopresti:2005; @Logan:1996], tested existing tools [@tpcclib]. goal facilitate open, explicit reproducible research. major features tacmagic documented walkthrough vignette included package. features include: loading TAC volume data analyze R, merging regional TAC data larger ROIs weighted volume, basic TAC plotting, calculation standardized uptake value ratio (SUVR) [@Lopresti:2005;@Dierckx:2014], calculation plotting non-invasive reference region Logan DVR model [@Logan:1996;@tpcclib] calculation cut-values dichotomizing data [@Aizenstein:2008]. package published open source licence, enabling future collaboration expansion package’s functions, may include future support additional data formats, kinetic models, plotting cut-calculation.

title: Cutoff value calculation using method described in Aizenstein et al. 2008 — cutoff_aiz
text: See reference tacmagic walkthrough vignette. Aizenstein et al. (2008) proposed standardized method calculating Pittsburgh Compound B (PIB) cutoff values classify participants PIB+ PIB-. used distribution volume ratio (DVR) several ROIs associated amyloid  deposition. steps summarized . cutoff_aiz() implements 1-3, returning cutoff values ROI. can used dichotomize participants, pos_anyroi().

text: Cutoff values ROI based method

title: Cutoff value calculation using method described in Aizenstein et al. 2008 — cutoff_aiz
text: 1. Remove outliers group cognitively normal individuals. outlier defined ROI DVR > upper inner fence ROI (= 3rd quartile + (1.5 * IQR). 2. Iterate step 1 needed outlying participants. 3. subset group outliers removed, cutoff value  ROI set upper inner fence.  4. participants, ROI cutoff  region, participant deemed PIB+.

title: Cutoff value calculation using method described in Aizenstein et al. 2008 — cutoff_aiz

what: Save a tac object as a .tac file — save_tac
title: Save a tac object as a .tac file — save_tac
text: Saves tac object, created load_tac(), tac_roi() manually,  saves PMOD-formatted tac file. Using .tac extension  file name recommended.

title: Save a tac object as a .tac file — save_tac
code: save_tac(tac, outfile)

title: Save a tac object as a .tac file — save_tac

what: Subset PMOD tacs with or without PVC — split_pvc
title: Subset PMOD tacs with or without PVC — split_pvc
text: partial volume correction (PVC) used PMOD, saved tac files ROIs without PVC. loaded load_tac()) may  desirable keep either PVC non-PVC tacs. returns tac  object subset input tac object PVC non-PVC tacs. relies PMOD's convention labelling tac columns "_C".

title: Subset PMOD tacs with or without PVC — split_pvc
code: split_pvc(tac, PVC = TRUE)

title: Subset PMOD tacs with or without PVC — split_pvc
text: tac time-activity curve data loading function (PMOD) PVC TRUE, includes columns "_C", FALSE, ones without "_C"

title: Subset PMOD tacs with or without PVC — split_pvc
text: Time-activity curve object

title: Subset PMOD tacs with or without PVC — split_pvc
code: # f_raw_tac and f_raw_vol are the filenames of PMOD-generated files f_raw_tac <- system.file("extdata", "AD06.tac", package="tacmagic")   tac <- load_tac(f_raw_tac) tac_pvc <- split_pvc(tac, TRUE) tac_nc <- split_pvc(tac, FALSE)

what: Calculate average SUV over time window, or maximum SUV — suv
title: Calculate average SUV over time window, or maximum SUV — suv
text: Calculate standardized uptake value (SUV) tac object, participant's weight, tracer dose. values may tac object manually supplied. weight must kg, tracer units must specified. dose converted MBq, tac converted kBq/cc, final SUV units thus g/cc. Aside tac object, remaining parameters left NULL required data tac object attributes (can done batch_load()).

title: Calculate average SUV over time window, or maximum SUV — suv
code: suv(tac, SUV_def, dose = NULL, dose_unit = NULL, weight_kg = NULL,   ...)

title: Calculate average SUV over time window, or maximum SUV — suv
text: tac time-activity curve object (decay-corrected) SUV_def vector start times window SUV weighted average, alternatively, "max" maximum ROI SUV value dose injected tracer dose dose_unit unit tracer dose (e.g. "MBq", "kBq", "mCi"...) weight_kg participant's weight kg ... called tm_batch, unused parameters may supplied

title: Calculate average SUV over time window, or maximum SUV — suv
text: table SUV values

title: Calculate average SUV over time window, or maximum SUV — suv
code: f <- system.file("extdata", "AD06.tac", package="tacmagic") fv <- system.file("extdata", "AD06_TAC.voistat", package="tacmagic") AD06_tac <- load_tac(f, format="PMOD") AD06_volume <- load_vol(fv, format="voistat") AD06 <- tac_roi(tac=AD06_tac, volumes=AD06_volume, ROI_def=roi_ham_pib(),                 merge=FALSE, PVC=FALSE) # dose and weight are fabricated for the example AD06_suvmax <- suv(AD06, "max", dose = 9.0, dose_unit = "mCi",                      weight_kg = 70) AD06_suv <- suv(AD06, c(3000, 3300, 3600), dose = 9.0, dose_unit = "mCi",                   weight_kg = 70)

what: tacmagic: PET Analysis in R — tacmagic
title: tacmagic: PET Analysis in R — tacmagic
text: main features tacmagic load PET time activity curve (tac) data  multiple formats, merge ROIs weighted volume, calculate binding  potential models including SUVR DVR, basic plotting, calculation  cut-values. Please see walkthrough vignette detailed overview.
